comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I hate to throw an elephant into a bath-tub...but... I've recently realised there are/were a Rawhiti I and a Rawhiti II...after encountering a couple of digitised newspaper hits which mention both yachts in action at the same regatta...just going on the digitised newspapers, I gather Rawhiti II came into being in ca. 1913... Thankfully, this 1927 SMH item on Frank Albert sheds light on the matter...it indicates that Rawhiti II was in fact the re-named Culwulla II - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16350445 SO ... I wonder whether maybe some of these pics of Rawhiti involve both Rawhiti I and Rawhiti II...the matter of distinguishing between the two might be quite difficult given both appear to have undergone rebuilds (Rawhiti I in 1910) or at least re-rigs (in the case of Rawhiti II)...my guess is that Rawhiti II might have passed out of circulation after 1922, given the digitised newspaper references to Rawhiti II don't continue beyond this date...one "Arrow" article (digitised but not yet available) indicates Frank Albert sold Rawhiti II in 1922...so maybe the name was then changed again...all up it appears that Rawhiti I and Rawhiti II would have been in circulation together in the period 1913-1922...so I'd say that most of the 1920s (and later) pics of 'Rawhiti' involve Rawhiti I... Here's the excellent ANMM item on Rawhiti I - emuseum.anmm.gov.au/code/emuseum.asp?style=browse&cur... ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14751402 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55655196 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14734437 ...Rawhiti I was brought to Australia by Arthur Pittar (evidently Pittar's house at Mona Rd, Darling Point, was also named Rawhiti)...then soon afterwards passed to Charles Brockhoff... nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28144116 - then in 1909/1910 to Ernest Sayer & Frank Albert... SMH item on Rawhiti's 1910 refit - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15184072 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article10764509 - 1913 Argus pic of the crew of Rawhiti II There was also a Rawhiti in Brisbane in the 1920s...but I haven't investigated its DNA...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[confused, but watching with interest]

Btw - it it 'Raw hitey' or 'Ra Whitey' or 'RaWhitty' or ... ?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hi all, our vessel expert has just said: 'Rawhiti II was a much smaller boat, a 6 metre class yacht about 30 feet long'.
And it also seems that photographs of Rawhiti II are more scarce than the first one. Thank you for all those links quasymody, an article on the Alberts and Rawhiti is coming soon so keep your eyes peeled :)
Also beachcomber, the official New Zealand way of saying it, which is where the vessel was built, is with an 'F' sound and the 'H' being silent, like 'Rafti'. The Aussies always called it 'Raw-Hiti', with other similar variations. Confusing, I'm barely getting the hang of it myself. ;)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Good to see the Rawhiti I v Rawhiti II issue has been sorted...and quickly too! One HMAS Australia v HMAS Canberra puzzle is enough for the time being!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103444547 - Just for interest, here's a newspaper item re what became of Rawhiti II. The recently digitised 'Arrow' might be a valuable source of info re yachting...and possibly life in general as well.
